'Victor Marie Hugo' (; 26 February 1802 â 22 May 1885) was a French poet,
novelist, and dramatist of the Romantic movement. He is considered one of the
greatest and best known French writers. In France, Hugo's literary fame comes
first from his poetry but also rests upon his novels and his dramatic
achievements. Among many volumes of poetry, [[:fr:Les Contemplations|Les
Contemplations]] and [[La LÃ©gende des siÃ¨cles]] stand particularly high in
critical esteem. Outside France, his best-known works are the novels [[Les
MisÃ©rables]], 1862, and Notre-Dame de Paris, 1831 (known in English as [[The
Hunchback of Notre-Dame]]).

Though a committed royalist when he was young, Hugo's views changed as the
decades passed; Â« When sufficient knowledge is only in one head, let this
head rule and that is monarchy; when it is in a few heads, let there heads rule
and that is aristocracy; when it is finally in all heads, let these heads rule
and it is democracy Â», in published Hugo archives by Pauvert he became a
passionate supporter of republicanism, and his work touches upon most of the
political and social issues and artistic trends of his time. He was buried in
the PanthÃ©on.
